added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import json class BaseModel(object): """Superclass Responsible for converting json data to/from model""" @classmethod def from_json(cls, json_str): return cls.from_dict(json.loads(json_str)) def to_json(self): return json.dumps(self.to_dict()) @classmethod def from_dict(cls, data): model = cls() for key in data: setattr(model, key, data.get(key)) return model def to_dict(self): result = {} for key in self.__dict__: result[key] = getattr(self, key) if isinstance(result[key], BaseModel): result[key] = result[key].to_dict() return result def __str__(self): return "%s" % self.to_dict() class EntityModel(BaseModel): """Superclass resposible from converting dict to instance of model""" @classmethod def from_dict(cls, data): model = super(EntityModel, cls).from_dict(data) if hasattr(model, cls.ENTITY_NAME): val = getattr(model, cls.ENTITY_NAME) setattr(model, cls.ENTITY_NAME, cls.MODEL_TYPE.from_dict(val)) return model class CollectionModel(BaseModel): """Superclass resposible from converting dict to list of models""" @classmethod def from_dict(cls, data): model = super(CollectionModel, cls).from_dict(data) collection = [] if hasattr(model, cls.COLLECTION_NAME): for d in getattr(model, cls.COLLECTION_NAME): collection.append(cls.MODEL_TYPE.from_dict(d)) setattr(model, cls.COLLECTION_NAME, collection) return model

commit_message:
[zmq] Make ZMQ TCP keepalive options configurable

Change-Id: Ib59c63b5dbbf74963b9c14dbabef03f35a42880c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/96/365696/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Configure TCP KA keepalive = self.conf.oslo_messaging_zmq.zmq_tcp_keepalive if keepalive < 0: keepalive = -1 elif keepalive > 0: keepalive = 1 self.handle.setsockopt(zmq.TCP_KEEPALIVE, keepalive) keepalive_idle = self.conf.oslo_messaging_zmq.zmq_tcp_keepalive_idle if keepalive_idle < 0: keepalive_idle = -1 self.handle.setsockopt(zmq.TCP_KEEPALIVE_IDLE, keepalive_idle) keepalive_cnt = self.conf.oslo_messaging_zmq.zmq_tcp_keepalive_cnt if keepalive_cnt < 0: keepalive_cnt = -1 self.handle.setsockopt(zmq.TCP_KEEPALIVE_CNT, keepalive_cnt) keepalive_intvl = self.conf.oslo_messaging_zmq.zmq_tcp_keepalive_intvl if keepalive_intvl < 0: keepalive_cnt = -1 self.handle.setsockopt(zmq.TCP_KEEPALIVE_INTVL, keepalive_intvl) self.handle.identity = \ six.b(str(uuid.uuid4())) if identity is None else identity
deleted_lines: self.handle.identity = six.b(str(uuid.uuid4())) if identity is None \ else identity

commit_message:
Allow for building specific images

It was not possible to build a single image if the yaml files passed
had multiple images defined. This adds a --image-name parameter to
tripleo-build-images to allow for that.

Change-Id: I5644656bbdc534f54c254edc7e939ae36f1f98ca
Closes-Bug: #1618566
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/95/363095/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch('yaml.load', autospec=True) @mock.patch('os.path.isfile', autospec=True) def test_load_config_files_single_image(self, mock_os_path_isfile, mock_yaml_load): mock_yaml_load.side_effect = [{ 'disk_images': [ { 'arch': 'amd64', 'imagename': 'overcloud', 'distro': 'some_awesome_distro', 'type': 'qcow2', 'elements': ['image_element'] }, { 'arch': 'amd64', 'imagename': 'not-overcloud', 'distro': 'some_other_distro', 'type': 'qcow2', 'elements': ['other_element'] } ]}] mock_os_path_isfile.return_value = True mock_open_context = mock.mock_open() mock_open_context().read.return_value = "YAML" with mock.patch('six.moves.builtins.open', mock_open_context): base_manager = BaseImageManager(['yamlfile1'], images=['not-overcloud']) disk_images = base_manager.load_config_files('disk_images') self.assertEqual(1, mock_yaml_load.call_count) self.assertEqual([{ 'arch': 'amd64', 'distro': 'some_other_distro', 'imagename': 'not-overcloud', 'type': 'qcow2', 'elements': ['other_element'], }], disk_images)

commit_message:
Fix route-generation process for l23_stored_config resource

also add some tests for cover it

Change-Id: I2f448d8ed5a2c81ab6a03e49b25583a2e450c613
Closes-bug: #1580581
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/19/318619/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: require 'spec_helper' describe Puppet::Type.type(:l23_stored_config) do before(:each) do puppet_debug_override() end it 'for ifconfig and addition routes' do catalog = Puppet::Resource::Catalog.new stored_config = Puppet::Type.type(:l23_stored_config).new( :name => "eth1", :onboot => "yes", :method => "static", :ipaddr => "169.254.1.3/24", :ipaddr_aliases => ["169.254.2.3/24", "169.254.3.3/24"], :provider => "lnx_ubuntu", :ensure => :present ) catalog.add_resource(stored_config) catalog.add_resource(Puppet::Type.type(:l3_route).new( :name => "10.1.0.0/16", :destination => "10.1.0.0/16", :gateway => "169.254.1.1", :metric => 10, :ensure => :present )) catalog.add_resource(Puppet::Type.type(:l3_route).new( :name => "10.2.0.0/16", :destination => "10.2.0.0/16", :gateway => "169.254.1.2", :ensure => :present )) catalog.add_resource(Puppet::Type.type(:l3_route).new( :name => "10.3.0.0/16", :destination => "10.3.0.0/16", :gateway => "169.254.3.1", :ensure => :present )) catalog.add_resource(Puppet::Type.type(:l3_route).new( :name => "10.9.0.0/16", :destination => "10.9.0.0/16", :gateway => "169.254.9.1", :ensure => :present )) stored_config.generate() expect(stored_config[:routes]).to eq({ "10.1.0.0/16" => {"gateway"=>"169.254.1.1", "destination"=>"10.1.0.0/16", "metric"=>"10"}, "10.2.0.0/16" => {"gateway"=>"169.254.1.2", "destination"=>"10.2.0.0/16"}, "10.3.0.0/16" => {"gateway"=>"169.254.3.1", "destination"=>"10.3.0.0/16"} }) end end # vim: set ts=2 sw=2 et

commit_message:
Clean imports in code

This patch set modifies lines which are importing objects
instead of modules. As per openstack import guide lines, user should
import modules in a file not objects.

http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#imports

Change-Id: I5b4bdcb674b58ab419d00ca9c6bff105ce19aca8

commit_message:
[placement] Add additional allocation tests

There was some concern that the placement service was not properly
attending to inventory constraints while trying to save allocations.
This change adds more test to cover some situations.

Related-Bug: #1620736

Change-Id: Icbb2d88eeae9a06d60f2071b660d4b7b6c1aa80d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/44/366144/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_allocation_exceeds_inventory(self): consumer_uuid = uuidsentinel.consumer # Create a resource provider rp1_name = uuidsentinel.rp1_name rp1_uuid = uuidsentinel.rp1_uuid rp1_class = fields.ResourceClass.DISK_GB rp1_used = 2048 rp1 = objects.ResourceProvider( self.context, name=rp1_name, uuid=rp1_uuid) rp1.create() # One allocation, exceeding capacity allocation_1 = objects.Allocation(resource_provider=rp1, consumer_id=consumer_uuid, resource_class=rp1_class, used=rp1_used) allocation_list = objects.AllocationList( self.context, objects=[allocation_1]) # Set the inventory with 1 < allocation ratio < 2 inv = objects.Inventory(resource_provider=rp1, resource_class=rp1_class, total=1024, allocation_ratio=1.9) inv.obj_set_defaults() inv_list = objects.InventoryList(objects=[inv]) rp1.set_inventory(inv_list) # Make the actual allocations self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidAllocationCapacityExceeded, allocation_list.create_all) # Set the inventory with allocation ratio < 1, total > rp1_used inv = objects.Inventory(resource_provider=rp1, resource_class=rp1_class, total=2048, allocation_ratio=.9) inv.obj_set_defaults() inv_list = objects.InventoryList(objects=[inv]) rp1.set_inventory(inv_list) # Make the actual allocations self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidAllocationCapacityExceeded, allocation_list.create_all) # Set the inventory with allocation ratio = 1, total = rp1_use inv = objects.Inventory(resource_provider=rp1, resource_class=rp1_class, total=2048, allocation_ratio=1) inv.obj_set_defaults() inv_list = objects.InventoryList(objects=[inv]) rp1.set_inventory(inv_list) # Make the actual allocations allocation_list.create_all() rp1_usage = objects.UsageList.get_all_by_resource_provider_uuid( self.context, rp1_uuid) self.assertEqual(rp1_used, rp1_usage[0].usage)
deleted_lines: # TODO(cdent): This does not currently behave as expected # because a new allocataion is created, adding to the total # used, not replacing.

commit_message:
Tweak 'nova-db-sync' and 'nova-db-sync-api' execs

This change adds retries to not fail on 'nova-manage' execution

Closes-Bug: #1619740
Change-Id: I33637b17a18f8809f0a5f3778c57d5066fd56b8d
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <mmalchuk@mirantis.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/78/366978/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # tweak both 'nova-db-sync' and 'nova-db-sync-api' execs if $primary_controller { Exec<| title == 'nova-db-sync' or title == 'nova-db-sync-api' |> { tries => '10', try_sleep => '5', } }

subject: Override name of shared baymodel
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-20 10:48:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/magnum/commit/e675992c3cc35d0d13bd9ec1b822ae7eeed7dcb5', 'message': "Duplicate named baymodel

Add a configuration directive 'allow_duplicate_baymodel_name',
default value is FALSE. If TRUE, duplicate named BayModel
resources will be allowed, as they are today. If FALSE, the name
of each baymodel need to be unique.

This way, by default Magnum requires a unique name, and cloud
operators can decide if they want to enforce name uniqueness or not.

In the case of clouds that want to allow sharing access to a BayModel
between multiple tenants (example: a global BayModel named 'k8s')
with 'allow_duplicate_baymodel_name' set to FALSE, a user will still
be allowed to create a BayModel with the name 'k8s' and it will
override the global one. If a user-supplied BayModel is present with
the same name as a global one, the one owned by the tenant would be
selected automatically.

Change-Id: Ia38e8816775469c0db666855f7fa23800def9e3c
Partially-Implements: blueprint duplicate-named-bay-and-baymodel

commit_message:
Override name of shared baymodel

Add a configuration directive 'allow_baymodel_name_override',
default value is TRUE. If TRUE, override name of shared BayModel
resources will be allowed, as they are today. If FALSE, the name
of new created baymodel need to be different with the shared
BayModel resources in other projects (note: if the new created
BayModel is in the same project with the shared one, then the
name of new created BayModel can be same with the shared one
whether 'allow_baymodel_name_override' is set to TRUE or not).

This way, by default Magnum allow override name of shared BayModel
and cloud operators can decide if they want to allow override or not.

In the case of clouds that want to allow sharing access to a BayModel
between multiple projects (example: a shared BayModel named 'k8s')
with 'allow_baymodel_name_override' set to TRUE, a user will still
be allowed to create a BayModel with the name 'k8s' and it will
override the shared one.

Change-Id: Ia38e8816775469c0db666855f7fa23800def9e3c
Implements: blueprint duplicate-named-bay-and-baymodel

commit_message:
Puppet4 support: l23network fixes

* nic_whitelist_to_json function should return nil if there are no
  whitelists.
* Remove the mutators for the frozen strings in the validator

Combined cherry-pock of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/367106/ & https://review.openstack.org/#/c/365028/

Change-Id: I89b2a487740fbe21de730527351bd33595403d42
Related-Bug: 1586480

commit_message:
Puppet4 support: fix noop launcher.

Cherry pick of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/364406/

Prevent false positive results in cases when something
is wrong with the environment and tests have not started at all.

commit_message:
Reduce the number of debug traces emitted by registry callbacks

The tool has become popular beyond my wildest expectations. A typical
run in the gate at debug level yields more than 20K traces in the
neutron-server alone. However, reducing the number of traces is
beneficial across the board and that's the first attempt at bringing
the size of Neutron logs closer to other services'.

Partial-bug: #1620864

Change-Id: I2576e59961ec8928ad71d778253b2d37d470d909

* fixed a minor bug in the registration spec

commit_message:
Add message for a result of update metadata

At the moment, even when a user update a metadata, this result is
not informed to a user (any message is not displayed).
So a user cannot know its result and he has to redisplay
'Update Metadata' modal in order to know its result.

Change-Id: I02b1a3c70d0225d2326d038b7519d49b0082985e
Closes-Bug: #1608361

commit_message:
Fixing auth for keystone v2.0

 * Patch https://review.openstack.org/364267 broke
   the compatibility with Keystone API v2.0
 * This patch fixes the backward compatibility
   with Keystone v2.0

commit_message:
Add material mapping for filter icon

The material theme is missing an icon for filter.
So, if a horizon plugin uses fa-filter,
the material theme just shows an empty box.

Change-Id: I7a7c6b337cf2a2906df9cb54c12e513d7a2c2c5e
Closes-Bug: #1621310

commit_message:
Modify the link to make more direct and clear

There should provide link for 'command-line interface for networking',
but the article provide the link for 'OpenStack End User Guide', so it
is not direct and accurate, so this patch provide the direct link and
delete the useless link.

Prep works for Py3 gate

set tox.ini to py34/py35 environment which is a part of unittest which
is runnable with py3 and fix some syntax errors from py3 to run them.

Replace default repos in multipath tests

For now proposed repos are not applied in multipath tests due to
own procedure of env setup. So, we need to add replace default repos

commit_message:
tripleo: enable voting for scenarios

Scenarios are now passing CI, we would like to enable voting so we can
start to gate on services we didn't gate before. It will improve the
quality of TripleO services and we won't break their deployment anymore.

See https://review.openstack.org/366427 results to see them passing
tests.

Change-Id: I36e36357253b1892e6feacb542e3714a34937969

commit_message:
[Rally] enable panko project in rally jobs

Currently rally gates are broken, since old api was deprecated and we need
to use panko instead.

Enabling panko to rally jobs will fix an issue :)

Change-Id: I719b558c15c9a6433d3cc2c7419509bd78709d95

commit_message:
Add jenkins-plugins-for-murano project to Openstack

The goal of the project is to develop and maintain a set of Jenkins
plugins that allows Jenkins to deploy Murano environments using
Jenkins.

This project is not a part of the Murano project because plugins
works inside Jenkins.

Change-Id: I68f6f1cf45a04bbf141871c095ce943c356cdf6a

commit_message:
Fix wrong warning about keystone version

The variable should be an array but we used string, so it
lead to incorrect warning in the httpd log.

Change-Id: I7a233338306e51ba11f2d80acfc758700f6bddd2
Closes-Bug: 1621137

commit_message:
Remove LXD tests from unsupported branches

The LXD tests should not be run on the stable/mitaka or liberty
branches. LXD functionality was only introduced in Newton.

Change-Id: I1538dc34ffe2a03e5fd11e2ee8f5be3901d796e5
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
fix logic for adding new release notes pages

Start by moving the steps to their own script so they are easier to test
locally. Then fix the logic for inserting new entries into the toctree
so it takes the indentation into account. This version assumes we're
standardizing on listing release notes in reverse chronological order,
and those changes will be made separately.

Change-Id: Ib1f74e05c36ba1d247c324c276cfc2d8d75d9420
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

to HasProject

commit_message:
Create fuel-nailgun-extension-iac project

This project is intended to be a Fuel LCM enhancement by intoducing
Infrastructure as Code concept. It provides Nailgun extension for
transformation OpenStack configuration files in data processed by
Fuel Library.

Change-Id: Ia3068dc0bdafc84d8f3c50785cd5641048377e50
Needed-By: I08abf91248f62296f5cb2e6bc33edccc03a1b412

Image URLs need update

which is causing failure to download images & checksum.

commit_message:
Add Dragonflow fullstack test for ML2 module

Dragonflow can be used in two modes: core-plugin and ml2 mechanism
driver. In an effort to support ML2 better, we would like to have a
continuous integration testing done on that configuration.

Change-Id: I5d54d022fc1fa4a0e87b946c37a2c3fb6d620886

subject: Raise NotImplementedError instead of NotImplemented
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-08 06:39:26.000000000', 'files': ['os_net_config/impl_eni.py', 'os_net_config/__init__.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-net-config/commit/db892bc5630eb5484440fc2511e2fe99e740df2b', 'message': 'Raise NotImplementedError instead of NotImplemented

NotImplementedError is the name of the exception
(https://docs.python.org/2/library/exceptions.html).
NotImplemented is the name of a constant
(https://docs.python.org/2/library/constants.html).
>>> raise NotImplemented()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<pyshell#0>", line 1, in <module>
    raise NotImplemented()
TypeError: 'NotImplementedType' object is not callable
>>> raise NotImplementedError()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<pyshell#1>", line 1, in <module>
    raise NotImplementedError()
NotImplementedError
This patch fix it.

Change-Id: I55ce4f09297f7be2472a6664435c2c9d9f86595c
'}]
commit_message:
Raise NotImplementedError instead of NotImplemented

NotImplementedError is the name of the exception
(https://docs.python.org/2/library/exceptions.html).
NotImplemented is the name of a constant
(https://docs.python.org/2/library/constants.html).
>>> raise NotImplemented()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<pyshell#0>", line 1, in <module>
    raise NotImplemented()
TypeError: 'NotImplementedType' object is not callable
>>> raise NotImplementedError()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<pyshell#1>", line 1, in <module>
    raise NotImplementedError()
NotImplementedError
This patch fix it.

Change-Id: I55ce4f09297f7be2472a6664435c2c9d9f86595c

commit_message:
Stop using mox in unit/consistencygroup/*.py tests

As mox is not compatible with python 3, all test cases that use
mox should be updated to use mock instead.

Replaced stubs.Set() with mock_object() in
cinder/tests/unit/consistencygroup/test_cg.py.

Change-Id: I5ac9f42a059f4d8d86eb1498e5003e359943f3be

commit_message:
Move element-info to a standard entry-point

Move element-info from a wrapper script to a standard entry-point
console_script.

Update the documentation to explain how to run it for development.  I
don't think we should support the idea that you can check-out the code
and run ./bin/disk-image-create -- it has dependencies (dib-utils,
etc) and needs to be run from a virtualenv (this is what CI in the
gate does).  A follow-up can clean-up some of the path munging stuff
we have for this in disk-image-create.

Change-Id: Ic0c03995667f320a27ac30441279f3e6abb6bca8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/45/367045/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Installation ============ For general use, you can use distribution packages or install via ``pip`` in a ``virtualenv`` For development purposes, you can use ``pip -e`` to install into a local development/testing ``virtualenv``, or use ``tox -e venv -- disk-image-create`` to run within a ``tox`` created environment.

commit_message:
Update reno for stable/newton

In addition to adding the new newton page, this fixes the existing
release notes build to show notes for unreleased versions, which ensures
that no poorly formatted release note breaks the release notes build.

It also fixes the toctree directive at the top of the release notes.

In order to support automatically updating the release notes when we
create stable branches, we want the pages to be in a standard order.
This patch updates the order to be reverse chronological, so the most
recent notes appear at the top.

Change-Id: I14bd797d49ff00cfca1d3113e5b0b87d66d42d70
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Except if tracked resource registered as countable

If a resource was registered in the quota engine before
being set as a tracked resource, it would have been registered
as a CountableResource instead of a TrackedResource.

This would cause a failure later when the resources were
being unregistered because the quota engine thought it
should have been a TrackedResource and tried to call
unregister_events on it.

This patch just prevents resources from being registered
as both types. It also callse unregister_all_resources as
part of the standard test case cleanup since the vast majority
of tests are using a plugin that may register resources.

Closes-Bug: #1612222
Change-Id: I8a40f38d7c0e5aeca257ba62115fa9b02ad5aa93

commit_message:
Raise NotImplementedError instead of NotImplemented

NotImplementedError is the name of the exception
(https://docs.python.org/2/library/exceptions.html).
NotImplemented is the name of a constant
(https://docs.python.org/2/library/constants.html).
>>> raise NotImplemented()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<pyshell#0>", line 1, in <module>
    raise NotImplemented()
TypeError: 'NotImplementedType' object is not callable
>>> raise NotImplementedError()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<pyshell#1>", line 1, in <module>
    raise NotImplementedError()
NotImplementedError
This patch fix it.

Change-Id: I49d09ba21ff86aaaa1080c38687aa0e46cdf12a6

commit_message:
Display correct number of total results

Due to a dependency on smart table in horizon,
the number of results displayed is not accurate.

This patch now shows the total number of hits and
the total number that are displayed (limited by the search limit).

Pagination is still handled through smart table. This will
be fixed in a future patch.

Change-Id: Ia00de35a76e4259f77e32581871bf3614e381dcc
Closes-Bug: 1616754

commit_message:
[WIP] Resync handler for trunks

Adds resync handler to agent.

Change-Id: Ie70242dba9602ee319bd2b75cd59a482c3db2f0f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/71/366571/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2016 SUSE Linux Products GmbH # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import Queue from oslo_log import log as logging from neutron._i18n import _LE, _LI from neutron.agent.common import ovs_lib from neutron.callbacks import events from neutron.callbacks import registry from neutron import context from neutron.services.trunk import constants from neutron.services.trunk.drivers.openvswitch.agent import trunk_manager from neutron.services.trunk.drivers.openvswitch import constants as t_const from neutron.services.trunk.rpc import agent LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) def is_parent_port(port_name): return port_name[:2] in trunk_manager.TrunkParentPort.DEV_PREFIX def generate_trunk_id_from_name(trunk_name): return trunk_name[len(t_const.TRUNK_BR_PREFIX):] class LocalTrunkBridge(ovs_lib.OVSBridge): def __init__(self, name, br_int): super(TrunkBridge, self).__init__(name) self.br_int = br_int self.parent_port_id = self._get_parent_port_id() self.db_model = None self.trunk_id = generate_trunk_id_from_name(name) self.interfaces = self.get_ports_attributes('Port') self.local_subports = self.get_subports_dict() def _get_parent_port_id(self): """Return the parent port id """ for iface in self.interfaces: if iface[:2] in trunk_manager.TrunkParentPort.DEV_PREFIX: return self.portid_from_external_ids(iface['external_ids']) return None def get_parent_port(self): """Returns parent port :returns : trunk_manager.TrunkParentPort object """ return trunk_manager.TrunkParentPort(self.trunk_id, self.parent_port_id) def get_subports_dict(self): """Returns dict of trunk_manager.Subport objects if trunk_id is present :return : dictionary of subports of the form [port_id] = trunk_manager.Subport """ for iface in self.interfaces: if not is_parent_port(iface['name']): port_id = self.portid_from_external_ids( iface['external_ids']) segmentation_id = self. subports[port_id] = trunk_manager.SubPort( self.trunk_id, port_id, segmentation_id=iface['tag']) return subports def exists(self): return self.bridge_exists(self.br_name) def unplug_subports(self): """Unplugs and removes the subports """ for subport in self.local_subports.values(): subport.unplug(self.br_int) def syc_with_db(self): """Syncs trunk bridge with db model of trunk - check the parent port id - for each subport check if it exists an if properties are correct (segementation-type, segmentation-id and port-id). Before any necessary changes to the subports, we need to unplug all incorrect subports before making any changes. """ parent_port_invalid = False # First look at parent_port # if self.db_model['port_id'] != self.parent_port_id: self.get_parent_port().unplug(self.br) parent_port_needs_to_be_plugged = True else: parent_port_needs_to_be_plugged = False # - check subports # Create a dictionary of subports in the db model indexed by the portid db_subports = {} for _port in self.db_model['sub_ports']: db_subports[_port['port_id']] = _port # Delete local subports whicha re not in the db model # or mark ports for update if necessary subports_need_update = [] for port_id in self.local_subports.keys(): if port_id not in db_subports.keys(): # delete (unplug) subport self.local_subports[port_id].unplug(self.br_int) else: db_port = db_subport[port_id] local_subport = self.local_subports[port_id] if local_subport.segmentation_id != db_port['segmentation_id']: subports_need_update.append(local_subport) # Unplug all ports which need updating for port in subports_need_update: port.unplug(self.br_int) # With everything that needs update uplugged, we can safely replug for port in subports_need_update: port.plug(self.br_int) if parent_port_needs_to_be_plugged: self.get_parent_port().plug(self.br_int) class ResyncHandler(object): local_trunks_queue = Queue.Queue() def __init__(self, br_int): # Register to listen to the appropriate events registry.subscribe(self.resync_trunks, t_const.OVSDB_RESYNC, events.AFTER_UPDATE) self.br_int = br_int self.trunk_manager = trunk_manager.TrunkManager(self.br_int) self.trunk_rpc = agent.TrunkStub() def resync_all_trunks(self, resource, event, trigger, ovsdb_events, ports_to_ignore): """Resyncs trunk bridges on the localhost with db models on server""" # First fill up the queue with the trunk bridges if self.local_trunks_queue.empty(): self.place_local_trunk_bridges_in_queue() # Next process the queue while self.local_trunks_queue.not_empty: try: local_trunk_br = self.local_trunks_queue.get(block=False) self._resync_local_trunk_br(local_trunk_br) # TODO(fitoduarte): the line above should be threaded. except Queue.Empty: break def _resync_local_trunk_br(self, trunk_br): """Resyncs local trunk bridge to db model in server. - requests db model of trunk from server - if server does not have a db model for the trunk, the trunk bridge will be removed locally - if the server returns a trunk model, the local trunk bridge is synced wit the model """ trunk_db_model = self.get_trunk_db_model(trunk_br) if trunk_db_model: trunk_br.set_db_model(trunk_db_model) trunk_br.sync_with_db() else: trunk_br.unplug_subports() trunk_br_parent_port = trunk_manager.TrunkParentPort( trunk_br.trunk_id, trunk_br.parent_port_id) trunk_br_parent_port.unplug(self.br_int) trunk_br.destroy() def get_trunk_db_model(self, trunk_br): """Returns db model for given trunk""" # TODO(fitoduarte): currently an rpc call is made for every trunk. # It would be great if we could get all db models # assigned to this agent in one single rpc call and # place them in a dictionary from which we could pull # the return value for this method. return self.trunk_rpc.get_trunk_details(context.get_admin_context(), trunk_br.parent_port_id) def _collect_local_trunk_brs(self): """Returns a list of the local trunk bridges with their parent port id """ trunk_brs = [] local_br_names = self._get_local_br_names() for br_name in local_br_names: if self._is_trunk_br(br_name): trunk_brs.append(LocalTrunkBridge(br_name, self.br_int)) return trunk_brs @staticmethod def _get_local_br_names(self): """Returns a list of bridges on the local host :return local_brs: a list of ovs_lib.OVSBridgeobjects """ ovs = ovs_lib.BaseOVS() return ovs.get_bridges() @staticmethod def _is_trunk_br(br): """Checks to see if a bridge is a trunk bridge :param br: ovs_lib.OVSBridge object representing the bridge """ return br.br_name.startswith(t_const.TRUNK_BR_PREFIX)

commit_message:
add newton  release and standardize release note page order

In order to support automatically updating the release notes
when we create stable branches, we want the pages to be in a
standard order. This patch add newton release and  updates the
order to be reverse chronological, so the most recent notes
appear at the top.

Change-Id: Ic89f3c71d64aed32cc839351d67ac13f128787c5

commit_message:
Fix deployment_tasks api, when graph_type is an empty string

Nailgun should treat and empty string, given to

/clusters/(?P<obj_id>\d+)/deployment_tasks/?graph_type=$
/clusters/(?P<obj_id>\d+)/deployment_tasks/plugins/?graph_type=$
/clusters/(?P<obj_id>\d+)/deployment_tasks/release/?graph_type=$
e.t.c.

as default graph type. So let's convert some 'false'
values to None in handlers.

Change-Id: I238764d24fc14b2a41baaca37dabb6264e7e91d8
Closes-Bug: #1576261
(cherry picked from commit e31b5b16ee3529cd835a05ec523c0c0731c0c671)

commit_message:
Remove user_id policy enforcement from unlock_override

Currently server unlock_override honor the user_id policy
rule enforcement which is not right as this is not destructive
action on resource.

This patch removes it from unlock_override.

Partially implements blueprint user_id_based_policy_enforcement

Change-Id: Ibec1ecfe3a452694f238e10c5da42a5c9179f5b9

commit_message:
Remove user_id policy enforcement from server start

Currently server start honor the user_id policy rule enforcement
which is not right as this is not destructive action on resource.

This patch removes it from server start action and corresponding tests
too.

Note- deleting test_start_policy_failed from test_serversV21.py as this
is duplicate of what we have in test_server_start_stop.py

Partially implements blueprint user_id_based_policy_enforcement

commit_message:
Config: change deprecation for max_fixed_ips_per_port to Ocata

Update the configuration help to indicate that this will be
deprecated in Ocata. Patches to provide an alternative solution
have been deferred to Ocata. So gthis will update the help
to ensure that it comes with an alternative solution.

The release note does not need to be updated as it indicates that
the variable will be deprecated in Newton or Ocata.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I9adb3391574016811b664d024856f2c5010130f0

subject: Convert OVO fields to primitives for to_dict()
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-05 14:39:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/1776b36e005d17340f24faf4523e902190a22c9f', 'message': "Convert OVO fields to primitives for to_dict()

to_dict() is used for conversions of OVO objects into
regular dictionaries to be used as plugin return values
to the API layer, etc. It provides the equivalent of
make_<resource>_dict that we use now (without the extension
processing). The values in these dictionaries should be
ready for representation in the API.

The issue was that the OVO to_dict() implementation was
placing complex types right into the dictionary which
would mean that the API would serialize them just by
calling str() on them (as part of json encoding). This
ignored the 'to_primitive' method defined on the OVO
type that defines how a field should be converted.
Therefore, when it came to timestamps to_dict() was
placing native datetime objects into the dictionary
which would convert to microsecond resolution, violating
the expected format of the OVO DateTime type.

This patch fixes the issue by calling 'to_primitive'
on each non-synthetic field in the to_dict() method
to ensure we match the expected format of the type before
we send it out the API.

Closes-Bug: #1620254

commit_message:
Convert OVO fields to primitives for to_dict()

to_dict() is used for conversions of OVO objects into
regular dictionaries to be used as plugin return values
to the API layer, etc. It provides the equivalent of
make_<resource>_dict that we use now (without the extension
processing). The values in these dictionaries should be
ready for representation in the API.

The issue was that the OVO to_dict() implementation was
placing complex types right into the dictionary which
would mean that the API would serialize them just by
calling str() on them (as part of json encoding). This
ignored the 'to_primitive' method defined on the OVO
type that defines how a field should be converted.
Therefore, when it came to timestamps to_dict() was
placing native datetime objects into the dictionary
which would convert to microsecond resolution, violating
the expected format of the OVO DateTime type.

This patch fixes the issue by calling 'to_primitive'
on each non-synthetic field in the to_dict() method
to ensure we match the expected format of the type before
we send it out the API.

Closes-Bug: #1620254
Change-Id: Ic0be54b1d4b23119e1458d4532e2f70bff0ff9f6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/84/365684/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_to_dict_makes_primitive_field_value(self): obj = self._test_class(self.context, **self.obj_fields[0]) dict_ = obj.to_dict() for k, v in dict_.items(): if k not in obj.fields: continue field = obj.fields[k] self.assertEqual(v, field.to_primitive(obj, k, getattr(obj, k)))

commit_message:
Use Reno for release note

OpenStack community manages thier project's release note with reno.
This patch adds releasenotes directory for Congress's release note.

http://docs.openstack.org/developer/reno/index.html

Change-Id: I66ed98659a6339974ede2a29b753881af54fe2f5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/98/365498/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Stop using mox in unit/scheduler/*.py tests

As mox is not compatible with python 3, all test cases that use
mox should be updated to use mock instead.

Replaced stubs.Set() with mock_object() in
cinder/tests/unit/scheduler/test_scheduler.py.

Change-Id: Id2d2fc485ff7420c1e263f6b8b970ddee3d82cf5

commit_message:
Move element-info a standard entry-point

Move element-info from a wrapper script to a standard entry-point
console_script.

Update the documentation to explain how to run it for development.  I
don't think we should support the idea that you can check-out the code
and run ./bin/disk-image-create -- it has dependencies (dib-utils,
etc) and needs to be run from a virtualenv (this is what CI in the
gate does).  A follow-up can clean-up some of the path munging stuff
we have for this in disk-image-create.

Change-Id: Ic0c03995667f320a27ac30441279f3e6abb6bca8

commit_message:
Implement elemental DSL parser

Change-Id: Idadc5810f3ac964901be1fa8c21236be205f9ac2
Partially-Implements: blueprint kolla-dsl
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/46/322346/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python import os import yaml class yml_parser(object): def __init__(self, yml_filename, distro, build_type, tag): self.distro = distro self.build_type = build_type self.tag = tag self.output = list() with open(yml_filename) as f: self.yml_data = yaml.safe_load(f) def parse_yum_repos(self, repo_data): for value in repo_data: if value[:4] == 'http': if value[len(value)-4:len(value)] == 'repo': repo_name = value[value.rfind('/'):] self.output.append('RUN curl %s -o /etc/yum.repos.d%s' % (value, repo_name)) else: self.output.append('RUN yum install -y %s && yum clean all' % value) else: self.output.append('COPY %s /etc/yum.repos.d/' % value) def parse_rpm_packages(self, package_data): counter = 0 total_len = len(package_data) for value in package_data: if counter == 0 and counter == total_len - 1: self.output.append('RUN yum -y install %s \\' % value) self.output.append(' && yum clean all') elif counter == 0: self.output.append('RUN yum -y install %s \\' % value) elif counter == total_len - 1: self.output.append(' %s \\' % value) self.output.append(' && yum clean all') else: self.output.append(' %s \\' % value) counter += 1 def parse_commands(self, native_data): copy = list() env = list() run = list() for value in native_data: if value[:4] == 'COPY': copy.append(value) if value[:3] == 'ENV': env.append(value) if value[:3] == 'RUN': run.append(value) for i in env: self.output.append(i) for i in copy: self.output.append(i) total_len = len(run) counter = 0 for value in run: if counter == total_len - 1: self.output.append(' && %s' % value[4:]) elif counter == 0: self.output.append('%s \\' % value) else: self.output.append(' && %s \\' % value[4:]) counter += 1 def parse_container(self, container_data, all_common, bin_common, src_common): if 'repos' in container_data: self.parse_yum_repos(container_data['repos']) if 'all_packages' in container_data: self.parse_rpm_packages(container_data['all_packages']) if self.build_type is 'binary': if 'bin_packages' in container_data: self.parse_rpm_packages(container_data['bin_packages']) else: if 'src_packages' in container_data: self.parse_rpm_packages(container_data['src_packages']) if 'all_commands' in container_data: self.parse_commands(container_data['all_commands']) if self.build_type is 'binary': if 'bin_commnads' in container_data: self.parse_rpm_packages(container_data['bin_commands']) else: if 'src_commands' in container_data: self.parse_rpm_packages(container_data['src_commands']) self.parse_commands(all_common) self.parse_commands(bin_common) self.parse_commands(src_common) def parse_and_output(self): for value in self.yml_data: del self.output[:] if 'parent' in self.yml_data[value][self.distro] and \ self.yml_data[value][self.distro]['parent'] == 'centos:7': self.output.append('FROM %s' % self.yml_data[value][self.distro]['parent']) else: self.output.append('FROM %s-%s-%s:%s' % \ (self.distro, self.build_type, self.yml_data[value]['parent'], self.tag)) self.all_commands = list() if 'all_commands' in self.yml_data[value]: self.all_commands = self.yml_data[value]['bin_commands'] self.bin_commands = list() if 'bin_commands' in self.yml_data[value]: self.bin_commands = self.yml_data[value]['bin_commands'] self.src_commands = list() if 'src_commands' in self.yml_data[value]: self.src_commands = self.yml_data[value]['src_commands'] self.parse_container(self.yml_data[value][self.distro], self.all_commands, self.bin_commands, self.src_commands) print 'Writing Dockerfile in %s/Dockerfile' % self.yml_data[value]['root'] f = open('%s/Dockerfile' % self.yml_data[value]['root'], 'w') for output_line in self.output: f.write('%s\n' % output_line) def main(): for root, dirs, files in os.walk("."): for file in files: if file == "elemental.yml": parse = yml_parser(os.path.join(root, file), 'centos', 'binary', '3.0.0') parse.parse_and_output() if __name__ == '__main__': main()

subject: Implements elemental.yml DSL for base
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-26 10:51:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/1767dbd78c739fc0929d867168dbe44460cffc8c', 'message': '[WIP] Prototyping feasibility of a DSL

This prototypes the feasibility of a DSL instead of the jinja2
templating we are currently using for docker file generation.

The problems with the jinja2 templates are numerous:
1. They must be maintained by a human
2. They cannot be programmatically modified
3. They generate alot of churn for little gain in the codebase
4. plugins are difficult
5. we have various ways of getting binaries into our containers
   which is poorly handled for custom binary types (like plugins)
   which make putting all that stuff in an ini file (build-conf.ini)
   not ideal.
6. on and on

a yml file has none of these problems.  This super rough prototype
generates most of the dockerfile for base for "centos/binary".

Change-Id: I6c359026cc17496d364c366a3d2c13c58faa72d9

'}, {'number': 13, 'created': '2016-05-27 19:21:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/871d6aa35150e92706d5e475c138aae459f8ef5b', 'message': '[WIP] Prototyping feasibility of a DSL

To use, run :
cd docker
./load.py

This will write aodh, base, and mariadb dockerfiles.

This prototypes  a DSL instead of the jinja2 templating we are currently
using for docker file generation.

The problems with the jinja2 templates are numerous:
1. They must be maintained by a human
2. They cannot be programmatically modified
3. They generate alot of churn for little gain in the codebase
4. plugins are difficult
5. we have various ways of getting binaries into our containers
   which is poorly handled for custom binary types (like plugins)
   which make putting all that stuff in an ini file (build-conf.ini)
   not ideal.

A yml file has none of these problems.  This rough prototype
generates dockerfiles for centos binary at present.

Change-Id: I6c359026cc17496d364c366a3d2c13c58faa72d9
'}, {'number': 14, 'created': '2016-05-27 21:54:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/f621275dc445147ce5a62121236c8bb2a02d8293', 'message': '[WIP] Prototyping feasibility of a DSL

commit_message:
Fixing auth for keystone v2.0

 * Patch https://review.openstack.org/364267 broke
   the compatibility with Keystone API v2.0
 * This patch fixes the backward compatibility
   with Keystone v2.0

Change-Id: I612595c8460f577f5dc51714843d00e090e8c7a6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-mistralclient refs/changes/55/365655/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if keystone.version == 'v2.0' and service: mistral_url = service[0].get(endpoint_type) elif service: mistral_url = service[0].get('url')
deleted_lines: mistral_url = service[0].get('url') if service else None

commit_message:
Stop using mox in unit/zonemanager/*.py tests

As mox is not compatible with python 3, all test cases that use
mox should be updated to use mock instead.

Replaced stubs.Set() with mock_object() in
cinder/tests/unit/zonemanager/test_fc_zone_manager.py.

Change-Id: I5ab25fba1559f3cdf55c2361c49251d755870a55
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/98/359598/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.mock_object(fc_zone_manager.ZoneManager, '_build_driver', fake_build_driver)

commit_message:
Ref count for dict item should be Py_DECREF

PyDict_SetItems doesn't steal the reference count so that the reference
count of each item in the dict should be decremented via Py_DECREF
*before* returning the dict to Python VM. Otherwise, those items can be
leaked which can never be collected as garbage.

The evicence for memory leak is avaialble for using debug mode python VM like:
https://gist.github.com/bloodeagle40234/f4c0cd267e085cc6224ffdc1b1822631

Plus, this patch add one unit test to check the memory increasement for
many call of get_segment_info.

Closes-Bug: #1604335

Change-Id: I6780efb9718017d296606f3c7e60684910584a1a

added_lines: // TODO: NULL handling for each item PyObject *segment_size_key = PyString_FromString("segment_size\0"); PyObject *segment_size_value = PyInt_FromLong(segment_size); PyObject *last_segment_size_key = PyString_FromString("last_segment_size\0"); PyObject *last_segment_size_value = PyInt_FromLong(last_segment_size); PyObject *fragment_size_key = PyString_FromString("fragment_size\0"); PyObject *fragment_size_value = PyInt_FromLong(fragment_size); PyObject *last_fragment_size_key = PyString_FromString("last_fragment_size\0"); PyObject *last_fragment_size_value = PyInt_FromLong(last_fragment_size); PyObject *num_segments_key = PyString_FromString("num_segments\0"); PyObject *num_segments_value = PyInt_FromLong(num_segments); if(PyDict_SetItem(ret_dict, segment_size_key, segment_size_value)){ pyeclib_c_seterr(-ENOMEM, "pyeclib_c_get_segment_info ERROR: "); ret_dict = NULL; goto exit; } if(PyDict_SetItem(ret_dict, last_segment_size_key, last_segment_size_value)){ pyeclib_c_seterr(-ENOMEM, "pyeclib_c_get_segment_info ERROR: "); ret_dict = NULL; goto exit; } if(PyDict_SetItem(ret_dict, fragment_size_key, fragment_size_value)){ pyeclib_c_seterr(-ENOMEM, "pyeclib_c_get_segment_info ERROR: "); ret_dict = NULL; goto exit; } if(PyDict_SetItem(ret_dict, last_fragment_size_key, last_fragment_size_value)){ pyeclib_c_seterr(-ENOMEM, "pyeclib_c_get_segment_info ERROR: "); ret_dict = NULL; goto exit; } if(PyDict_SetItem(ret_dict, num_segments_key, num_segments_value)){ pyeclib_c_seterr(-ENOMEM, "pyeclib_c_get_segment_info ERROR: "); ret_dict = NULL; goto exit; } Py_DECREF(segment_size_key); Py_DECREF(segment_size_value); Py_DECREF(last_segment_size_key); Py_DECREF(last_segment_size_value); Py_DECREF(fragment_size_key); Py_DECREF(fragment_size_value); Py_DECREF(last_fragment_size_key); Py_DECREF(last_fragment_size_value); Py_DECREF(num_segments_key); Py_DECREF(num_segments_value); } exit: return ret_dict;

commit_message:
Update info in the configuration file

Since there are so many components in openstack,
by describing the URL info in the configuration file,
it is more convenient to find the developer documentation than
from the unified portal.

Change-Id: I071fd5c05a9e88f1384942b06f939c84ff3fa8c7
Closes-Bug: #1621083

commit_message:
Correct fragment size handling

Once we have liberasurecode older than depend-on patch, it could make
an invalid mem access if the backend descripter is not available.
(I'm not sure this situation happen in fact, but any other functions in
liberasurecode expecting that failure actually, FWIW)

To recover this failure, this patch fixes to catch the return value from
liberasurecode and if it's an error code, set an error for the return
value to python.

Depends-On: I489f8b5d049610863b5e0b477b6ff70ead245b55
Change-Id: I47d4ec4fa1647c5a4c8d50f0aa6a2df86ca68c80

commit_message:
Convert pkg-map and svc-map copies to explicit variables

Using the explicit variables, these elements don't have to walk the
path to find the files in other elements; they can extract it directly

Change-Id: I0a64b45e9f2cfa28e84b2859d76b065a6c4590f0

added_lines: elements = yaml.decode(os.environ.get("IMAGE_ELEMENT_YAML")) for element, path in elements.items(): data_path = os.path.join(path, "svc-map") if os.path.exists(data_path): with open(data_path, 'r') as dataFile: data = yaml.load(dataFile.read()) try: service_names = merge_data( data, service_names, os.environ.get("DISTRO_NAME")) except Exception as err: print("%s. Check %s for duplicate" " service name." % (err, element)) sys.exit(1)
deleted_lines: elements = os.environ.get("IMAGE_ELEMENT").split(' ') element_paths = os.environ.get("ELEMENTS_PATH").split(':') for element in elements: if not element.strip(): continue for element_path in element_paths: data_path = os.path.join(element_path, element, "svc-map") if os.path.exists(data_path): with open(data_path, 'r') as dataFile: data = yaml.load(dataFile.read()) try: service_names = merge_data( data, service_names, os.environ.get("DISTRO_NAME")) except Exception as err: print("%s. Check %s for duplicate" " service name." % (err, element)) sys.exit(1)

commit_message:
Add IMAGE_ELEMENT_YAML

This new variable is a YAML formatted list of the elements chosen for
the build along with their full paths.

This list is intended for consumption of elements who need to copy
files from other elements, such as pkg-map and svc-map.  As discussed
in I2a29861c67de2d25c595cb35d850e92807d26ac6, this list has already
been pruned and had overrides processed, so it is safe to simply walk
over this list with no further processing.

Since we're presenting the element list in a couple of different ways,
we combine it all into the element-info script.  It will output an
eval-able string that declares the appropriate variables.

I've added some inline documentation so they still appear in grep.
The documentation is updated with examples, and moved to a more
appropriate location as a sub-section of the element sytle guide.

To test this out, use the associative-array in generate_hooks, where
we can now find the element's directory without searching.

Change-Id: Ibbd07d082ec827441def2d3f6240df3efdc6eae3

Firstly we want to make the override policy for elements completely

directories in ELEMENT_PATHS in *reverse* order -- that is to say,
earlier entries in the paths will overwrite later ones.

 ELEMENT_PATHS=foo:bar:baz

will mean that "foo/element" will override "baz/element", since "foo"
is first.  This should be sane to anyone familiar with $PATH.

elements we have chosen.  We want the aforementioned elements that
walk the element list to use these canonical paths to pickup files;
this way they don't need to make local decisions about element
overrides, but can simply iterate a list and copy/merge files if they
exist.

expose this data in a separate variable that can be parsed by elements
(a further follow-on I0a64b45e9f2cfa28e84b2859d76b065a6c4590f0
modifies the elements to use this information).  Thus this does not
change the status-quo -- elements that are walking ELEMENTS_PATH
themselves and can/will continue doing that.

commit_message:
Making element overriding explicit

This is a re-factor of element_dependencies to achieve two things --
centralising override policy and storing path names.

Firstly we want to make the override policy for elements completely
explicit.  Currently, elements that wish to copy parts of other
elements walk ELEMENTS_PATH themselves and look for elements in
IMAGE_ELEMENT.  How they handle duplicate elements can differ, leading
to inconsistent behaviour.

We introduce logic in element-info to find elements in each of the
directories in ELEMENT_PATHS in *reverse* order -- that is to say,
earlier entries in the paths will overwrite later ones.

For example

 ELEMENT_PATHS=foo:bar:baz

will mean that "foo/element" will override "baz/element", since "foo"
is first.  This should be sane to anyone familiar with $PATH.
Documentation is clarified around this point and a test-case is added.

The second thing is that we want to keep the complete path of the
elements we have chosen.  We want the aforementioned elements that
walk the element list to use these canonical paths to pickup files;
this way they don't need to make local decisions about element
overrides, but can simply iterate a list and copy/merge files if they
exist.

A follow-on change (I7092e1845942f249175933d67ab121188f3511fd) will
expose this data in a separate variable that can be parsed by elements
(a further follow-on I0a64b45e9f2cfa28e84b2859d76b065a6c4590f0
modifies the elements to use this information).  Thus this does not
change the status-quo -- elements that are walking ELEMENTS_PATH
themselves and can/will continue doing that.

Change-Id: I2a29861c67de2d25c595cb35d850e92807d26ac6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/85/334785/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import errnoclass Element(object): """An element""" def __init__(self, name, path, provides=None, depends=None): self.name = name self.path = path self.provides = set() self.depends = set() # read the provides & depends files for this element into a # set; if the element has them. provides = os.path.join(path, 'element-provides') depends = os.path.join(path, 'element-deps') try: with open(provides) as p: self.provides = set([line.strip() for line in p]) except IOError as e: if e.errno == errno.ENOENT: pass else: raise try: with open(depends) as d: self.depends = set([line.strip() for line in d]) except IOError as e: if e.errno == errno.ENOENT: pass else: raise logger.debug("New element : %s", str(self)) def __str__(self): return '%s p:<%s> d:<%s>' % (self.name, ','.join(self.provides), ','.join(self.depends)) def expand_dependencies(user_elements, all_elements): :param all_elements: Element object dictionary from find_all_elements elif element not in all_elements: logger.error("Element '%s' not found", element) sys.exit(1) element_obj = all_elements[element] element_deps = element_obj.depends element_provides = element_obj.providesdef find_all_elements(paths=None): """Build a dictionary Element() objects Walk ELEMENTS_PATH and find all elements. Make an Element object for each element we wish to consider. Note we process overrides such that elements specified earlier in the ELEMENTS_PATH override those seen later. :param paths: A list of paths to find elements in. If None will use ELEMENTS_PATH :return: a dictionary of all elements """ all_elements = {} # note we process the later entries *first*, so that earlier # entries will override later ones. i.e. with # ELEMENTS_PATH=path1:path2:path3 # we want the elements in "path1" to override "path3" if not paths: paths = reversed(get_elements_dir().split(':')) for path in paths: if not os.path.isdir(path): logger.error("ELEMENT_PATH entry '%s' is not a directory", path) sys.exit(1) # In words : make a list of directories in "path". Since an # element is a directory, this is our list of elements. elements = [os.path.realpath(os.path.join(path, f)) for f in os.listdir(path) if os.path.isdir(os.path.join(path, f))] for element in elements: # the element name is the last part of the full path in # element (these are all directories, we know that from # above) name = os.path.basename(element) new_element = Element(name, element) if name in all_elements: logger.warning("Element <%s> overrides <%s>", new_element.path, all_elements[name].path) all_elements[name] = new_element return all_elements all_elements = find_all_elements() print(' '.join(expand_dependencies(args.elements, all_elements)))
deleted_lines: def _get_set(element, fname, elements_dir=None): if elements_dir is None: elements_dir = get_elements_dir() for path in elements_dir.split(':'): element_deps_path = (os.path.join(path, element, fname)) try: with open(element_deps_path) as element_deps: return set([line.strip() for line in element_deps]) except IOError as e: if os.path.exists(os.path.join(path, element)) and e.errno == 2: return set() if e.errno == 2: continue else: raise logger.error("Element '%s' not found in '%s'" % (element, elements_dir)) sys.exit(-1) def provides(element, elements_dir=None): """Return the set of elements provided by the specified element. :param element: name of a single element :param elements_dir: the elements dir to read from. If not supplied, inferred by calling get_elements_dir(). :return: a set just containing all elements that the specified element provides. """ return _get_set(element, 'element-provides', elements_dir) def dependencies(element, elements_dir=None): """Return the non-transitive set of dependencies for a single element. :param element: name of a single element :param elements_dir: the elements dir to read from. If not supplied, inferred by calling get_elements_dir(). :return: a set just containing all elements that the specified element depends on. """ return _get_set(element, 'element-deps', elements_dir) def expand_dependencies(user_elements, elements_dir=None): :param elements_dir: the elements dir to read from. Passed directly to dependencies() element_deps = dependencies(element, elements_dir) element_provides = provides(element, elements_dir) print(' '.join(expand_dependencies(args.elements)))

commit_message:
devstack: fix aodh-api launch

This now uses the pbr wsgi_scripts facility, so the current command line is
invalid. Let's remove -v and -d as debug level is conrtolled by
$ENABLE_DEBUG_LOG_LEVEL. The configfile is hardcoded to the default location in
settings, so there's no neeed to pass it too.

Change-Id: I6d13c17d32017544b8fa8411fdef4af86a7b0a4d
Closes-Bug: #1620880
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/aodh refs/changes/44/366544/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: run_process aodh-api "$AODH_BIN_DIR/aodh-api"

subject: Raise NotImplementedError instead of NotImplemented
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-01 02:48:39.000000000', 'files': ['searchlight/plugin.py', 'searchlight/elasticsearch/plugins/base.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/searchlight/commit/004bfc17afcbe841af44b121c8c7a089f1439c0c', 'message': 'Raise NotImplementedError instead of NotImplemented

NotImplementedError is the name of the exception
(https://docs.python.org/2/library/exceptions.html).

NotImplemented is the name of a constant
(https://docs.python.org/2/library/constants.html).

>>> raise NotImplemented()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<pyshell#4>", line 1, in <module>
    raise NotImplemented()
TypeError: 'NotImplementedType' object is not callable

>>> raise NotImplementedError()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<pyshell#5>", line 1, in <module>
    raise NotImplementedError()
NotImplementedError

This patch fix it.

Change-Id: Ia6157f1137300a6c5c4c0e52fd1a46ccc29a9564
Closes-Bug: #1339855
'}]
commit_message:
Raise NotImplementedError instead of NotImplemented

NotImplementedError is the name of the exception
(https://docs.python.org/2/library/exceptions.html).

NotImplemented is the name of a constant
(https://docs.python.org/2/library/constants.html).

>>> raise NotImplemented()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<pyshell#4>", line 1, in <module>
    raise NotImplemented()
TypeError: 'NotImplementedType' object is not callable

>>> raise NotImplementedError()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<pyshell#5>", line 1, in <module>
    raise NotImplementedError()
NotImplementedError

This patch fix it.

Change-Id: Ia6157f1137300a6c5c4c0e52fd1a46ccc29a9564
Closes-Bug: #1339855
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/searchlight refs/changes/33/364033/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: raise NotImplementedError()

commit_message:
Build trust for receiver creation

This patch adds trust building logic for receiver creation.

Change-Id: I42131c79ab9ea0b7edfe68df18aa423081e721da
Partial-bp: message-based-receiver
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/63/365463/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: return "".join(["trust+", base, sub_url]) raise exc.EResourceCreation(type='trust', return trust.id trust_id = self._build_trust() LOG.error(trust_id) LOG.error(subscriber) "subject": "hello, senlin", "trust_id": trust_id # Pop subscription and trust_id from channel info since it # should be invisible for user.
deleted_lines: # TODO(Yanyanhu): building trust for subscription. trust = self._build_trust() LOG.error(trust) #return "".join(["trust+", base, sub_url]) return "".join([base, sub_url]) return trust raise exc.EResourceCreation(type='subscription', def _build_trust(self): zaqar_user = 'zaqar' try: zaqar_user = self.keystone().user_get(zaqar_user) trust = self.keystone().trust_get_by_trustor(self.user, zaqar_user.id, self.project) except exc.InternalError as ex: msg = _('Can not build trust between user %(user)s and zaqar ' 'service user %(zaqar)s for receiver %(receiver)s.' ) % {'user': self.user, 'zaqar': zaqar_user, 'receiver': self.id} LOG.error(msg) raise exc.EResourceCreation(type='subscription', message=ex.message) "subject": "hello, senlin" # Pop subscription from channel info since it should be # invisible for user.

commit_message:
Delete dependencies when deleting a node or cluster

When deleting a node or cluster which has containers running on it,
the action should be forbidden. When deleing a container node, the
dependency information stored in the host node and cluster should
also be removed.

Change-Id: I8a1ddf2c3bdcd048045cce34435ab6cd255e4796

commit_message:
Project domain must match role domain for assignment

When assigning a Domain specific role to a user it is OK if the user
is from a different domain, but the project's domain must match the
role's domain.

Closes-Bug: 1590587
Change-Id: I1d63415de0130794939998c3e142ebdce9ddf39d

commit_message:
Add get_by_desc ret val handling to get_fragment_size

As well as any other callers, libersurecode_get_fragment_size should
handle the return value of liberasurecode_get_backend_instance_by_desc.

Otherwise, get_by_desc can return NULL and it causes an invalid memory
access in librerasurecode_get_fragment_size.

Change-Id: I489f8b5d049610863b5e0b477b6ff70ead245b55
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/liberasurecode refs/changes/16/341016/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * @param size - (int*) a pointer of integer to store * sizeof(fragment_header) + size * + frag_backend_metadata_size as a return value * * @return 0 on success, otherwise non-zero error codeint liberasurecode_get_fragment_size(int desc, int data_len, int* size);
deleted_lines: * * @return fragment size - sizeof(fragment_header) + size * + frag_backend_metadata_sizeint liberasurecode_get_fragment_size(int desc, int data_len);

commit_message:
Separate encryption_types_client from types_client

The is_resource_deleted() of types_client covers both volume_type and
encryption_type and the method interface became different from the
other service client, because the existence check way is different
from both resources. That is not so good for stable interface and
it is nice to separate encryption_type way to simple code.

Partially implements blueprint consistent-service-method-names

Change-Id: If4ecd61d2886d616b677d8bbeaf31646cb1b19cd

added_lines: i). Create a sample-vnfd.yaml file with the following content: tosca_definitions_version: tosca_simple_profile_for_nfv_1_0_0 description: Demo example metadata: template_name: sample-tosca-vnfd topology_template: node_templates: VDU1: type: tosca.nodes.nfv.VDU.Tacker capabilities: nfv_compute: properties: num_cpus: 1 mem_size: 512 MB disk_size: 1 GB properties: image: cirros-0.3.4-x86_64-uec availability_zone: nova mgmt_driver: noop config: | param0: key1 param1: key2 CP1: type: tosca.nodes.nfv.CP.Tacker properties: management: true anti_spoofing_protection: false requirements: - virtualLink: node: VL1 - virtualBinding: node: VDU1 CP2: type: tosca.nodes.nfv.CP.Tacker properties: anti_spoofing_protection: false requirements: - virtualLink: node: VL2 - virtualBinding: node: VDU1 CP3: type: tosca.nodes.nfv.CP.Tacker properties: anti_spoofing_protection: false requirements: - virtualLink: node: VL3 - virtualBinding: node: VDU1 VL1: type: tosca.nodes.nfv.VL properties: network_name: net_mgmt vendor: Tacker VL2: type: tosca.nodes.nfv.VL properties: network_name: net0 vendor: Tacker VL3: type: tosca.nodes.nfv.VL properties: network_name: net1 vendor: Tacker tacker vnfd-create --vnfd-file sample-vnfd.yaml <NAME>

commit_message:
Remove six.moves module

Python 3 reorganized the standard library and moved several functions to
different modules. Six provides a consistent interface to them through the
fake six.moves module.

But six.StringIO is an alias for StringIO.StringIO in Python 2 and
io.StringIO in Python 3. So we don't need six.moves.StringIO() any more,
we use six.StringIO() directly.

Here is links :http://pythonhosted.org/six/#module-six.moves

Change-Id: I44dbe915820ba4b5ffc0e34812fadc3d905542d1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-senlinclient refs/changes/08/366608/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.stringio = six.StringIO()
deleted_lines: from six import moves self.stringio = moves.StringIO()

commit_message:
Better handle vim domain exception

Instead of handling each keystone parameter error in Tacker,
reuse keystone's BadRequest exception that already takes care of
parameter errors in user input not just for domains, but users,
projects and tenants.

Change-Id: I2a6aa6f7f9dec829bf1010d244d1aadf7942ec9d

commit_message:
Make shell main() specify return value in exit code

sys.exit() calls in main() will make the interactive
python interpreter exit. We can call the main() as
below to avoid to exit the interactive interpreter,
and specify the return value of main() in the exit
code at the same time.
sys.exit(main())

also see: I6ead9853fe27e99df3e9121478e906a06839f48c

Change-Id: I3086dc0529c4343f246f543de1b6ee6540438a98
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-senlinclient refs/changes/07/366507/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: return 130 return 1 sys.exit(main())

commit_message:
Keystone endpoints should go before the service

  This commit sets up a relationship in Class[swift::keystone::auth] so
  at to guarantee that all endpoints are setup before launching any
  swift services.

Change-Id: I95476d5a61787d5c27c46d9daa84f62911c24183
(cherry picked from commit 6a434381500c0eb1a362d97e8ebaa511f585b5a9)

commit_message:
Establish cinder_type after keystone_endpoint

  The commit adds a collector of cinter_type requiring
  Keystone_endpoint if any configure_endpoint parameter is set.

  Without this it is easily possible for resources using the cinder_type
  to run before any endpoints are created, failing the catalog run.

Change-Id: I13a6a44ee28b4b314fd806690ef292da2ebd6cd0
(cherry picked from commit 65851eed7f215a61b7b5915c9d42994868bcebd9)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-cinder refs/changes/51/366951/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Convert pkg-map and svc-map copies to explicit variables

Using the explicit variables, these elements don't have to walk the
path to find the files in other elements; they can extract it directly

Change-Id: I0a64b45e9f2cfa28e84b2859d76b065a6c4590f0

commit_message:
Add IMAGE_ELEMENT_YAML and get_image_element_array

These new variables are a list of elements chosen for the build along
with their full paths.  For Python elements, IMAGE_ELEMENT_YAML is a
YAML formatted list that can be easily parsed.  For bash elements,
"get_image_element_array" will produce an associative-array of the
same (working around lack of array export in Bash).

This list is intended for consumption of elements who need to copy
files from other elements, such as pkg-map and svc-map.  As discussed
in I2a29861c67de2d25c595cb35d850e92807d26ac6, this list has already
been pruned and had overrides processed, so it is safe to simply walk
over this list with no further processing.

Since we're presenting the element list in a couple of different ways,
we combine it all into the element-info script.  It will output an
eval-able string that declares the appropriate variables.

I've added some inline documentation so they still appear in grep.
The documentation is updated with examples, and moved to a more
appropriate location as a sub-section of the element sytle guide.

To test this out, use the associative-array in generate_hooks, where
we can now find the element's directory without searching.

Change-Id: Ibbd07d082ec827441def2d3f6240df3efdc6eae3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/36/367036/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Making element overriding explicit
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-08 01:11:24.000000000', 'files': ['releasenotes/notes/element-override-ccda78c24ab4a4ff.yaml', 'diskimage_builder/tests/test_elementdeps.py', 'diskimage_builder/element_dependencies.py', 'doc/source/developer/invocation.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/274be6de551883fc14e3af30f84ba5bdf829814e', 'message': 'Making element overriding explicit

This is a re-factor of element_dependencies to achieve two things --
centralising override policy and storing path names.

Firstly we want to make the override policy for elements completely
explicit.  Currently, elements that wish to copy parts of other
elements walk ELEMENTS_PATH themselves and look for elements in
IMAGE_ELEMENT.  How they handle duplicate elements can differ, leading
to inconsistent behaviour.

We introduce logic in element-info to find elements in each of the
directories in ELEMENT_PATHS in *reverse* order -- that is to say,
earlier entries in the paths will overwrite later ones.

For example

 ELEMENT_PATHS=foo:bar:baz

will mean that "foo/element" will override "baz/element", since "foo"
is first.  This should be sane to anyone familiar with $PATH.
Documentation is clarified around this point and a test-case is added.

The second thing is that we want to keep the complete path of the
elements we have chosen.  We want the aforementioned elements that
walk the element list to use these canonical paths to pickup files;
this way they don't need to make local decisions about element
overrides, but can simply iterate a list and copy/merge files if they
exist.

A follow-on change (I7092e1845942f249175933d67ab121188f3511fd) will
expose this data in a separate variable that can be parsed by elements
(a further follow-on I0a64b45e9f2cfa28e84b2859d76b065a6c4590f0
modifies the elements to use this information).  Thus this does not
change the status-quo -- elements that are walking ELEMENTS_PATH
themselves and can/will continue doing that.

Change-Id: I2a29861c67de2d25c595cb35d850e92807d26ac6
'}]
commit_message:
Making element overriding explicit

This is a re-factor of element_dependencies to achieve two things --
centralising override policy and storing path names.

Firstly we want to make the override policy for elements completely
explicit.  Currently, elements that wish to copy parts of other
elements walk ELEMENTS_PATH themselves and look for elements in
IMAGE_ELEMENT.  How they handle duplicate elements can differ, leading
to inconsistent behaviour.

We introduce logic in element-info to find elements in each of the
directories in ELEMENT_PATHS in *reverse* order -- that is to say,
earlier entries in the paths will overwrite later ones.

For example

 ELEMENT_PATHS=foo:bar:baz

will mean that "foo/element" will override "baz/element", since "foo"
is first.  This should be sane to anyone familiar with $PATH.
Documentation is clarified around this point and a test-case is added.

The second thing is that we want to keep the complete path of the
elements we have chosen.  We want the aforementioned elements that
walk the element list to use these canonical paths to pickup files;
this way they don't need to make local decisions about element
overrides, but can simply iterate a list and copy/merge files if they
exist.

A follow-on change (I7092e1845942f249175933d67ab121188f3511fd) will
expose this data in a separate variable that can be parsed by elements
(a further follow-on I0a64b45e9f2cfa28e84b2859d76b065a6c4590f0
modifies the elements to use this information).  Thus this does not
change the status-quo -- elements that are walking ELEMENTS_PATH
themselves and can/will continue doing that.

Change-Id: I2a29861c67de2d25c595cb35d850e92807d26ac6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/35/367035/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: The variable ``ELEMENTS_PATH`` is a colon (:) separated path list to search for elements. The included ``elements`` tree is used when no path is supplied and is always added to the end of the path if a path is supplied. Earlier elements will override later elements, i.e. with ``ELEMENTS_PATH=foo:bar`` the element ``my-element`` will be chosen from ``foo/my-element`` over ``bar/my-element``, or any in-built element of the same name.
deleted_lines: Using the variable ``ELEMENTS_PATH`` will allow to specify multiple elements locations. It is a colon (:) separated path list, and it will work in a first path/element found, first served approach. The included elements tree is used when no path is supplied, and is added to the end of the path if a path is supplied.

commit_message:
Stop using mox in unit/backup/drivers/*.py

As mox is not compatible with python 3, all test cases that use
mox should be updated to use mock instead.

Replaced stubs.Set() with mock_object() in some classes in
cinder/tests/unit/backup/drivers/.

Change-Id: Id4905d0172dd4cbf6fe0006720b8ca2f3f1200c8

commit_message:
Ensure endpoints created before admin_token_auth

  This commit will establish that all endpoints are created before the
  admin_token_auth is removed from the authentication pipeline.

  Without this you can no guarantee that all required endpoints are
  bootstrapped properly on initial puppet run.

Change-Id: I43b4ca8d623c2447e722fd521a5375f828858802
(cherry picked from commit 04d49698b12539e8494b01ecff415aee8975c3c5)

commit_message:
Turn off bindep

bindep installs a slew of stuff we don't really need and doesn't add
much if any value.  This only turns on bindeps that are required.

This shaves about 3 minutes off each gate run.

Closes-Bug: #1620865
Change-Id: I24df4f2a30c682c1b09e89c7c52f7608582da1a6

commit_message:
Tweak not found exception handling

Use ResourceNotFound class to unify class NodeNotFound,
ClusterNotFound, PolicyNotFound, PolicyNotFound.

This patch also added an 'enhance_msg' function to fine tune the message
text.

Add '.' analysis in class SenlinException.

Change-Id: I0fc07858739b909577bcfbb0fb07704353db9d1e

commit_message:
Revert "Switch fernet to be the default token provider"

This reverts commit 181588b9ba50fefea12617a9a5e774daddfed20c.

Since this change landed on 4/29 it's been the cause of the
top two gate failures (besides known latent infra issues) and
hasn't had good progress on landing a fix, so until it's a
priority for the keystone team we need to revert this change
to get the integrated gate jobs moving again.

Change-Id: I588a84c5179eab072d21bc1394aea2df00929650
Related-Bug: #1577558
Related-Bug: #1578866

commit_message:
Update reno for stable/newton

In order to support automatically updating the release notes when we
create stable branches, we want the pages to be in a standard order.
This patch updates the order to be reverse chronological, so the most
recent notes appear at the top.

Change-Id: Id5b7f4216a9a55249601827896703a6c87991eba
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
